item.title: Harry Potter: Quidditch Champions Would Be Wise to Dig Deep for Playable Characters
item.description:
Highlights

  • September 3 marks the launch of Harry Potter: Quidditch Champions, promising stylish animations and intuitive game mechanics for fans.
  • The game could benefit from diving deeper into Wizarding World lore, including historical Quidditch figures like the Kneen family.
  • In addition to classic characters like Harry and Draco, Quidditch Champions could explore 'What if?' scenarios with unconventional match-ups.

Though last year's Hogwarts Legacy was met with some really positive reviews from both fans and critics alike, one sizable criticism was the game's lack of a Quidditch mode. A staple of most Harry Potter movie tie-in games, Quidditch has appeared in various video game forms over the last few decades, and fans were hoping it would appear bigger and better than ever in Hogwarts Legacy . But while fans were left a bit disappointed last year, Harry Potter: Quidditch Champions could be about to fill that void.

Set for a September 3 launch, Harry Potter: Quidditch Champions looks like it's shaping up nicely, with its last few gameplay trailers showing off some stylish animations and some seemingly intuitive game mechanics. A recent trailer also confirmed that players will be able to make their own custom character, or choose from a variety of familiar faces, with Harry Potter, Draco Malfoy, Cho Chang, and a slew of Weasleys already confirmed to appear. While this is already a decent roster for Harry Potter: Quidditch Champions , the game could dig even deeper into its source material.

Harry Potter: Quidditch Champions Should Think Outside The Box for its Roster

Harry Potter: Quidditch Champions Should Dig Out Some Historical Players

While Harry Potter: Quidditch Champions is already set to include some iconic series characters, it would be great to see the game dive deeper into Wizarding World lore to deliver some lesser-known Quidditch figures. According to the current Harry Potter canon, Quidditch in its most recognizable form was first invented all the way back in the early 11th century near the marshes of Queerditch. One of the earliest named Quidditch players was the witch Gwenog, whose friend Gertie Keddle was responsible for noting the existence of the first-ever Quidditch matches in her diary.

A century later, Quidditch had become a popular sport for witches and wizards across Britain, with the Yorkshire-based Kneen family being some of the most prominent historical figures related to the sport. Goodwin Kneen and his wife Gunhilda Kneen were both avid Quidditch players, and were partly responsible for spreading the sport to the rest of the world, as they detailed the game's rules in a letter to their Norwegian cousin Olaf. It would be great to see these historical characters appear in Harry Potter: Quidditch Champions , maybe alongside an old-timey pitch that uses mounted barrels as goalposts as opposed to the usual golden hoops.

Harry Potter: Quidditch Champions could also find some inspiration in the Wizarding World's more recent history, delivering a handful of characters who were known to play the game just before this latest generation of competitors. James Potter – Harry's father – would be a great pick for Harry Potter: Quidditch Champions , with him having canonically played for Gryffindor back during his Hogwarts days.

Harry Potter: Quidditch Champions Could Deliver a Few 'What If?' Players

On top of players from Quidditch's long history, Harry Potter: Quidditch Champions could include a wealth of iconic franchise characters who may not have canonically played the sport in either the books or movies, but are ones fans would probably like to see in the game regardless. Classic Harry Potter characters like Hermione, Neville, and Luna would all be great to see in the game. Quidditch Champions could get even wilder with its 'What if?' picks by allowing less conventional matches such as ones between iconic Hogwarts teachers like Snape, Dumbledore, and even Hagrid, or ones between Hogwarts' ghost inhabitants like Peeves and Nearly Headless Nick, though that might be pushing the franchise's canon a bit too far.

item.title: New York Times Strands Hints and Answers for August 19, 2024
item.description:
Quick Links

  • The NYT Games Strands Puzzle #169 August 19, 2024
  • New York Times Games Strands Clues
  • Spoilers for Two of the Words in Today's Strands
  • The Answer to Today's New York Times Games Strands
  • Today's Strands Explained

Strands is a short word puzzle game that you can play every day. It was created by the New York Times Games, the same company that is famous for its Crosswords and other daily word puzzles.

Today's puzzle is up and ready for you to try out, but if you are stuck, you have some options. The rules of Strands allows for an in-game hint system, but if you're not a fan for some reason, you can find helpful hints in the article below instead.

The NYT Games Strands Puzzle #169 August 19, 2024

The Strands puzzle for today has the clue Hear Me Roar! It has eight items to find: one Spangram and seven themed words.

New York Times Games Strands Clues

For some spoiler-free clues for this free-to-play PC game, check out the three sections below. They will help you get closer to the theme without ruining any of the eight words hidden in this puzzle.

General Hint 1

General Hint 2

General Hint 3

Spoilers for Two of the Words in Today's Strands

Each of the expandable sections below contains one spoiled word and its position in this browser game, in case you want to see a spoiler but don't want to go through the trouble of finding non-themed words to save up for a hint. Press the Read More button below each one to uncover it.

Spoiler 1

Spoiler 2

The Answer to Today's New York Times Games Strands

The full answer to this mobile device-friendly puzzle game is in the section below. Click the Read More button to uncover all the themed words, the Spangram, and where each goes in a completed puzzle.

Today's Strands Explained

If you want to see an explanation for the puzzle, look into the section below. It will layout how the clue and themed words go together in today's Strands puzzle.

Want to play? Check out the New York Times Games Strands website available on almost any device with a browser.

item.title: Persona 5 Royal: The 11 Best Gifts You Can Give Ann
item.description:
Highlights

  • Ann Takamaki is a beloved character in Persona 5 Royal , whether players pursue a romantic relationship or not.
  • Strengthening her Confidant bond will benefit players with various helpful abilities and unlockable content.
  • Choosing the right gifts for Ann, such as Wrist Weights or the Face Beautifier, can deepen your relationship with her.

Ann Takamaki is a potential love interest in Persona 5 Royal , but aside from that, she's also a great friend to Joker if the player doesn't decide to pursue a romantic relationship with her. Either way, players will love spending time with her while progressing her Confidant.

She's the Confidant of The Lovers Arcana and can strengthen any Persona that's attached to this category. She's an incredibly kind person, and as such, should be given plenty of gifts! Since she's obsessed with shopping and that's the best way to further Joker's relationship with her, it only makes sense that players can find most of the things she likes best at various malls.

Updated on August 17th, 2024, by Ritwik Mitra: Persona 5 is one of the greatest JRPGs ever, and introduced many people to a series that started out as a Shin Megami Tensei spin-off before becoming one of Atlus' biggest golden geese. The wait for Persona 6 is agonizing and fans can't wait to see what the next game in the series has in store for them. A huge part of what made the fifth mainline Persona game such a joy to play through is the many Confidants that players can interact with, including their party members. Ann Takamaki is one such party member whom players will love to hang out with, and people who don't want the downtime with this character to be wasted should check out the best gifts for Ann in Persona 5, which will be a source of great delight for her.

Honorable Mention: Best Of KGB49

Bonus: +2

  • In-game Description: "Complete history of KGB49 from start to present. May make a nice gift."
  • Where to Find: Babel Records Music Store in the Underground Mall
  • Price: ¥3,000

KGB49 is presumably a popular band in the universe of Persona 5 Royal , although there's not much mention of them anywhere else in the game. It's a kind gesture for Ann as a Confidant, since she must like their music, but it would be great to know a bit more about them.

Still, despite fans not having an inkling about this band, that doesn't change the fact that Best of KGB49 is one of the best gifts for Ann in Persona 5 . It goes a long way in improving her relationship with Joker and ensures that players can enjoy steady progress with her Confidant relationship without wasting too much time. However, this gift is only an honorable mention, as it is only available in Persona 5, and was removed in Persona 5 Royal.

11 Wrist Weights

Bonus: +2

  • In-game Description: "Body-building tools for arms and legs. For the exercise enthusiast."
  • Where to Find: Next Ace sports shop in the Underground Mall
  • Price: ¥6,800

Ann lives a hectic life. Juggling her life as a student, model, and member of the Phantom Thieves is easier said than done. She must stay in shape to ensure that her modeling work isn't impeded, which is why she'll love a gift that lets her stay in shape on the go.

The Wrist Weights are useful gifts, and quite thoughtful, as one of the best gifts for Ann in Persona 5 . It's one of the many presents that will help Joker get close to this character.

10 Bath Of Roses

Bonus: +3

  • In-game Description: "A rose-scented fragrance for a luxurious bathtime. For the special lady in your life."
  • Where to Find: Flower Shop Sukebe in Shinjuku
  • Price: ¥3,200

Sometimes, the simplest and most obvious gifts are the ones that people will appreciate the most. Such is the case with the Bath of Roses, which is a simple way to earn Ann's affection and help Joker progress her Confidant level.

The Bath of Roses is one of the best gifts for Ann in Persona 5 and can do a great job of deepening her bond with Joker. The +3 bonus is a valuable one, and players need only make a quick trip to Shinjuku to purchase a gift that will impress Ann quite a bit.

9 Blaring Alarm Clock

Bonus: +2

  • In-game Description: "Ultra-loud clock to wake up any sleepyhead. For the busy businessperson."
  • Where to Find: Electronics Superstore Akindo in Akihabara
  • Price: ¥12,000

Most people would assume that getting an alarm clock is easily one of the most annoying gifts that anyone can get. However, it seems that many people like to wake up on time, including Ann.

As a result, the Blaring Alarm Clock becomes another great gift for this Phantom Thief. Her packed schedule mandates that she wakes up on time and is punctual enough to not anger anyone, making this gift perfect for her.

8 Chocolate Truffles

Bonus: +3

  • In-game Description: "Chocolate truffles made with meticulous detail. For the sweet tooth."
  • Where to Find: Taisho Store Premium Supermarket in the Underground Mall
  • Price: ¥2,800

Chocolates are an easy gift that anyone would like, and Ann is no exception. She loves her fair share of sweets, and one of the best gifts for Ann in Persona 5 will ensure that Joker can leave her happy after spending some valuable time with her.

These truffles are as tasty as they come if Ann loves this gift so much. The best part is that Chocolate Truffles can be obtained in the same locations where Ann usually hangs out, letting players snag a quick gift if they have to experience a generic Confidant event.

7 Face Beautifier

Bonus: +3

  • In-game Description: "A face massager that can slim your face quickly. For the rising star."
  • Where to Find: Electronics Superstore Akindo in Akihabara
  • Price: ¥9,800

It's clear that a beautiful face is a desirable trait in the universe of Persona 5 Royal . This is understandable, and someone like Ann who wants to be a successful model would appreciate anything that allows her to enhance her looks and become a top model.

This is why the Face Beautifier is one of the best gifts for Ann in Persona 5 , letting her enhance her looks and make her more appealing as a model. It's a no-brainer gift that players find in Akihabara, and players don't need to worry about Ann looking at this gift the wrong way.

6 Star Mirror

Bonus: +3

  • In-game Description: "A star-shaped mirror that's supposed to be lucky. For a spiritual someone."
  • Where to Find: Furniture/General Store Mran Mran in Shinjuku
  • Price: ¥9,800

This one might come off as a bit of a surprise, especially because Ann Takamaki doesn't come off as a spiritual person so much as somewhat vain, even if her heart's in the right place. Either way, the mirror fulfills a purpose and she likes it to the highest degree possible in the game.

This Star Mirror is one of the best gifts for Ann in Persona 5 , but a lot of people aren't aware of it. Having a reflective surface she can whip out to see how she looks from time to time is bound to help her out during her part-time job.

5 Castella

Bonus: +3

  • In-game Description: "Sponge cake topped with coarse sugar. For someone with a sweet tooth."
  • Where to Find: Taisho Store Premium Supermarket in the Underground Mall
  • Price: ¥1,500

While food might be kind of a strange gift depending on who the people involved in the situation are, there are plenty of different types of foods available in the game. One of the two that Ann likes is Castella .

This sweet treat is one of the best gifts for Ann in Persona 5 which is perfect for her sweet tooth. Every sweet gift in the game is perfect for Ann, and the Castella is no exception here.

4 Uji Matcha Flan

Bonus: +3

  • In-game Description: "Pudding made from uji matcha green tea. For the sweet tooth."
  • Where to Find: Taisho Store Premium Supermarket in the Underground Mall
  • Price: ¥2,400

For those who aren't aware of where matcha comes from, it's mostly derived from traditional ceremonial tea ceremonies where the popular Sencha green tea was ground up. While traditionally Matcha was bitter, its use in various pastries and lattes has made for a bit of an updated sweet taste.

This has turned the Uji Matcha Flan into one of the sweetest treats that people from Japan can enjoy. It's one of the best gifts for Ann in Persona 5 , which is obvious given her penchant for sweet things.

3 Heart Ring

Bonus: +3

  • In-game Description: "A ring inset with a heart-shaped jewel. Made to captivate a woman's heart."
  • Where to Find: Tsurukame Diamond in the Underground Mall
  • Price: ¥88,000

The Heart Ring is one of the most expensive items in the game, coming in at a whopping 88,000 yen. It's not only one of the best gifts for Ann in Persona 5 , but most other girls will also love this piece of jewelry.

While it's extremely expensive, it only makes sense considering it's very fancy. Even though there aren't any items that imply romantic attention necessarily, this seems like it would be.

2 Crimson Lipstick

Bonus: +3

  • In-game Description: "An intensely red lipstick worn by a popular model. For the fashion-conscious."
  • Where to Find: Body Chop Cosmetic Store in the Underground Mall
  • Price: ¥6,000

It seems a little odd that the description mentions that there's a famous model who frequently wears makeup, it makes sense that Ann if anyone would be into the Crimson Lipstick . Still weird that a model would be popular enough among the general public to make it a highly sought-after gift, but here it is.

Ann's job mandates that she looks good no matter what. This is why the Crimson Lipstick is one of the best gifts for Ann in Persona 5 , which should be obvious if players pay attention to what she does and likes.

1 Designer Perfume

Bonus: +2

  • In-game Description: "A famous brand of perfume with a gentle scent. For a sensual person in your life."
  • Where to Find: Body Chop Cosmetic Store in the Underground Mall
  • Price: ¥7,800

Perfume is an easy gift to give people as long as they don't get offended by the insinuations that they don't smell good. Thankfully, Ann is smart enough to not be offended by such a gesture, and it's easy to see why fans might miss one of the best gifts for Ann in Persona 5 Royal because of how effective it is, despite this potential misconception.

This simplifies one of the best gifts for Ann in Persona 5 , which isn't necessarily a bad thing. She's quite grateful, and her friendship level with Joker increases a ton as a result.

item.title: How Halo Infinite Could Have Become Xbox's Own Fortnite
item.description:
Highlights

  • Halo Infinite started strong but faltered due to lack of content, leading to lost interest among players.
  • The game was initially planned to be a live-service platform like Fortnite, with a 10-year roadmap.
  • Halo could have had its own unique game modes and content, but fell short of realizing its full potential.

It's been a long and tough road for Halo Infinite . Upon its initial launch back in 2021, Halo Infinite was met with a great deal of praise from both critics and fans, with many citing the game's multiplayer as a great return to the series' arena shooter roots, and many enjoying the campaign's attempt to push the franchise in a new direction. But as a live-service game, Halo Infinite 's cracks soon started to show.

Too few multiplayer maps, a disappointing lack of staple modes like Forge and campaign co-op, and an inconsistent post-launch roadmap combined to slowly kill interest in Halo Infinite . While developer 343 Industries has spent the last few years bringing those requested features to the game, it's a far cry from what Halo Infinite was originally supposed to be, and if things had worked out differently, Xbox could have had its own version of Fortnite.

Halo Infinite Could Have Been Xbox's Fortnite

Halo Infinite Once Had a 10-Year Plan

Back in July 2020 – immediately following Halo Infinite 's eagerly-awaited first gameplay reveal – IGN interviewed former Infinite studio head Chris Lee. During the interview, Lee referred to Halo Infinite as "the start of [343's] platform for the future," and that the game would mark the "start of the next ten years for Halo." Lee doubled down on this plan, stating that "numbered" Halo titles wouldn't be happening again for a while. Despite repeatedly affirming that Halo Infinite was not a live-service game, 343 Industries' comments at the time suggested the exact opposite, and if all went to plan, then Halo Infinite could have been in the same boat as Fortnite by now.

Halo Infinite Could Have Been a Platform Like Fortnite

Though 343 Industries never gave any concrete details related to its 10-year plan for Halo Infinite , it seems safe to assume that it would have involved an even greater amount of post-launch support than the game ended up receiving. On top of additions like campaign co-op, new maps, new weapons, and new cosmetics, Halo Infinite 's 10-year plan probably would have included more story content for the game and more drastic changes for its multiplayer mode, evolving the title's gameplay and visuals over time.

But Halo Infinite 's 10-year plan could have really set the world on fire if it took a page out of Fortnite 's playbook. In the last few years, Fortnite has become an entire gaming platform in its own right. What began as just a simple PvE horde game quickly turned into the biggest battle royale on the planet, and with the addition of Creative mode, Fortnite became an exponentially bigger title, giving players the tools to create their own smaller-scale games inside Fortnite itself. And that was only the beginning.

Last year, Fortnite added the kart racer Rocket Racing, the Rock Band -like Fortnite Festival, and the survival mode LEGO Fortnite to its ever-growing platform. Each mode is essentially its own standalone game, offering tens of hours of content completely for free. In an alternate universe, Halo Infinite could have been a platform like Fortnite , with its own Flood-based horde mode, its own Creative mode with Forge, and even its own LEGO Fortnite mode with a Halo Mega Bloks tie-in.

item.title: 5 Open-World Games With High Difficulty Curves
item.description:
Difficulty in games is a wholly subjective topic, as every player is different; what some may find tremendously easy, others may struggle with. While many games offer multiple difficulty options, some (such as Dark Souls ) omit them entirely. Overly difficult games can turn some players away, but some offer truly rewarding experiences for those that stick it out.

Even with multiple difficulty options, some games continuously challenge players from the outset. This can make them inaccessible, unforgiving, and at-times frustrating. However, open-world games often allow players to approach challenges in a non-linear fashion, and exploration can provide a welcome respite from constant challenges. Even with this approach, some of the best open-world games deliver a sharp challenge due to their high difficulty curve.

5 STALKER: Shadow Of Chernobyl

An Inaccessible But Immersive Experience

STALKER: Shadow of Chernobyl isn't necessarily the hardest game out there, but players can often bounce right off of it from the very start. Some of this can be attributed to its rough edges and increasing age, but STALKER: Shadow of Chernobyl has a variety of systems and nuances that players need to learn before they're able to survive in its interconnected open world.

STALKER: Shadow of Chernobyl is a first-person open-world RPG with elements of survival horror, with a heavy dose of resource management and a variety of nasty creatures tossed in for good measure. However, these creatures aren't the only thing trying to kill the player, and they'll often be caught in visceral, dangerous gunfights with opposing factions. Learning how to prepare for a journey and how to maneuver during combat can take some getting used to, but this is only part of what makes STALKER: Shadow of Chernobyl , and its sequels, so unique.

4 Kingdom Come: Deliverance

Strategic First-Person Combat In A Medieval Open World

Featuring a faithfully constructed medieval setting, Kingdom Come: Deliverance is an immersive first-person RPG that takes place in a historical open world. Taking on quests and exploring its world are frequently engaging, but the game's combat will be a deal-breaker for many players.

It's an acquired taste, but Kingdom Come: Deliverance features truly challenging combat that rewards patience, skill, and strategy. Taking on multiple enemies at once is never a good idea, and over-committing to an attack is almost always punished. This unforgiving combat provides a challenge that can be inconsistent, but it delivers a rewarding system for players to learn over the course of the game.

3 The Long Dark

Hardcore Survival In A Remarkably Tranquil World

Quiet, contemplative, and deeply unforgiving, The Long Dark is a hardcore survival game that puts players in a frozen wilderness and tasks them with nothing but staying alive. While players will have to deal with wild wolves and the occasional bear, wildlife is often the least of their concerns. There are a variety of ways to perish in The Long Dark , and being injured or even killed by wildlife is just one of many ways to go.

Freezing to death, or starving, is more likely. Players may begin the game in good condition — perhaps they'll find a stash of goods — but eventually, those goods will run out, and their condition will begin to wane. This prompts the player to go out and explore, inevitably bombarding them with more problems to solve. Learning The Long Dark's many intricacies takes hours of play, but its remarkably quiet world can offer a tranquil experience when everything's going right.

2 Kenshi

A Deeply Replayable Sandbox That's More Than Meets The Eye

Kenshi is a party-based RPG that may not look like much on the surface, but it offers a tremendous amount of player agency and an expansive open world to explore. This world, however, is extremely hostile, and surviving in it is no small feat. It's fairly easy to die in Kenshi , with plenty of potential threats roaming the world at all times. Furthermore, the game's busy user interface is somewhat unfriendly to newcomers.

In Kenshi , players begin with control over just one character but can soon gather an entire company of characters (should they wish). Learning how to make money, do battle, build a base, and simply survive in its world takes potentially hours of gameplay. What's more, Kenshi doesn't hold the player's hand, instead letting them loose in the world. While this can be frustrating at first, it's part of what makes Kenshi so rewarding — and so replayable.

1 Elden Ring

An Expansive Open World With Classic Soulslike Challenge

FromSoftware are notorious for developing games with high difficulty curves, as seen in the Dark Souls series and perhaps more notably in Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice . Although Dark Souls is far from linear, much of its world is gated off, and players are carefully steered down a select few paths. In a way, Dark Souls shares more in common with Metroidvanias than full open-world games.

One of FromSoftware's latest video games, Elden Ring , is different; in Elden Ring , players are free to explore the world in whatever order they see fit. This world is much more expansive, providing players with stretches of land to explore, dotted with landmarks and memorable locations. The world also features a variety of dungeons that vary in both difficulty and engagement. Despite this change to the formula, Elden Ring maintains the high difficulty curve that the Dark Souls games are known for, offering a truly challenging open-world experience.
